awd_titl_txt: STEM Scholars: Persistence and Achievement in STEM  for Community College transfer students
awd_abstract_narration:
Scholarships for academically strong STEM students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, have an impact on the number of STEM graduates prepared to help regional and local companies compete and innovate in the global economy.  This project will increase the number of academically talented, economically disadvantaged STEM transfer students who complete baccalaureate degrees in biology and chemistry at Samford University in order to develop the STEM workforce in Central Alabama.  Approximately 40 scholars will participate in a two-year program, designed to maximize academic success, social support, and career development.  The project will build on partnerships that were initiated with two nearby 2-year colleges (Lawson and Jefferson State Community Colleges) during a prior NSF-REU award.  The institutions will conduct joint research symposia, seminars, professional society meetings, and STEM recruitment events and establish faculty exchanges.  

Recognizing that providing transitional support structures is critical in promoting academic success and retaining transfer students, the project team will utilize a variety of high- impact practices including learning communities, academic tracking, and close advising.  Moreover, the scholars will participate in a four-day Transfer Success Seminar to orient them to academic life at a 4-year institution and cultivate a group identity within the cohort.  The findings from the project evaluation will help to contribute evidence that will improve our understanding of best practices for supporting STEM community college transfer students through to graduation.  Formative evaluation will address the student's satisfaction and identification as scientists (SALG) and faculty assessment of the students' progress (rubrics).  Summative evaluation will consist of an analysis of how well the project components align with successful attainment of the retention targets.  In addition, internship employers will be surveyed. Dissemination of the results of evaluation will be done through websites, national meetings (the University of New Mexico Mentoring Institute Mentoring Conference, the Ecological Society of America, the American Chemical Society and the Biennial Conference on Chemical Education, and relevant journals (the Journal of Research in Science Teaching and the Journal of Chemical Education).

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this S-STEM grant was to help community college students who were academically talented and financially-at-risk transfer to Samford University and complete bachelor’s degrees in STEM fields, including biology, chemistry and biochemistry, computer science, environmental science, marine science, math, and physics. Although more than 50% of college students begin at community colleges, there is a “transfer penalty” and only 45% of community college students graduate within six (6) years of transfer [See: Handel, S.J. & R.A. Williams. 2012. The Promise of the Transfer Pathway: Opportunity and Challenge for Community College Students Seeking the Baccalaureate Degree. The Initiative on Transfer Policy and Practice. College Board Advocacy and Policy Center. https://secure-media.collegeboard.org/digitalServices/pdf/professionals/handel-williams-the-promise-of-the-transfer-pathway-summary.pdf.]

The stated aim of the Samford STEM Scholars Program was to graduate 70% of the entering students by providing community, career, academic, and financial support. Over the course of the grant, the Program supported 32 students, of whom 26 graduated. This 81% success rate is almost double the national average reported in the 2012 survey by Handel and Williams.  This success was achieved through community building in an orientation and one-semester (1-credit) STEM foundations course; strong academic support; intentional and intrusive mentoring; and excellent student services, including a Career Development Center, Writing Center, and Office of Diversity and Intercultural Initiatives.

The biggest contribution to the success of the Samford STEM Scholars Program in retaining and graduating students was the one-semester (1-credit) STEM foundations course that prepared students for internships or research experiences. The course emphasized writing, self-presentation, and communication skills that are essential to career success. This course-based approach to community building, retention, and STEM career preparation was novel and effective. Although only 28 students had the foundations course, we documented that the training and professional development it provided significantly increased their ability to see themselves as scientists, to persist to graduation (93% of students), and to find employment after graduation. A full 92% of graduates had STEM employment or were in a STEM graduate program within three months after graduation. 

An additional goal of the Samford STEM Scholars Program was to increase the number of students from groups underrepresented in STEM employed in science, computer science or mathematics. The Program was also successful in meeting this goal. Because some local community colleges are majority-minority institutions, student from groups underrepresented in STEM were 56% of our entering students and 58% of our graduates. The highest graduation rate (100%) was among Hispanic/Latina graduates, with all but one immediately employed in the STEM work force. The STEM Scholars who were Black and White had similar graduation rates, 80% and 78.5% respectively, and the Black students were 100% successful in achieving immediate STEM employment or advanced educational opportunities upon graduation.

The Samford STEM Scholars Program successfully partnered with local community colleges to help their students achieve 4-year degrees and enter careers or advanced education in STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2023
Modified by: Elizabeth G Dobbins
